review.title: Use of the C4.5 machine learning algorithm to test a clinical guideline-based decision support system
review.abstract: Well-designed medical decision support system (DSS) have been shown to improve health care quality. However, before they can be used in real clinical situations, these systems must be extensively tested, to ensure that they conform to the clinical guidelines (CG) on which they are based. Existing methods cannot be used for the systematic testing of all possible test cases. We describe here a new exhaustive dynamic verification method. In this method, the DSS is considered to be a black box, and the Quinlan C4.5 algorithm is used to build a decision tree from an exhaustive set of DSS input vectors and outputs. This method was successfully used for the testing of a medical DSS relating to chronic diseases: the ASTI critiquing module for type 2 diabetes.

sections.heading: 1 Methods
sections.text: We propose a general verification method with three steps: (1) generation of a comprehensive set of possible input vectors for the DSS and execution of the DSS to determine the output for each input vector; (2) extraction of knowledge from the set of (input vector, output result) pairs by applying learning or generalization algorithms; and (3) comparison of the knowledge extracted in step 2 with the original knowledge source (here the CG) by an expert.

sections.heading: 1.1 Generating Input Vectors and Outputs
sections.text: It is possible to create a complete (or almost complete) set of input vectors by taking into account a set of variables expressing the different elements of input for the DSS and generating all possible combinations of the values of the variables. Continuous variables (e.g. glycosylated hemoglobin) are limited to a few values corresponding, for example, to the thresholds expressed in the CG. Finally, the output associated with each input vector is obtained by executing the DSS.

sections.heading: 1.2 Building the Decision Tree
sections.text: Using C4.5 [13], a reference algorithm in machine learning, a decision tree is built from the input vectors and the associated results, and the cut must be deactivated to ensure a 0% error in the tree. Factorization rules are applied to reduce the size of the tree: (1) If all the children of a particular node contain the same element of a recommendation (e.g. a recommended drug treatment), this information element can be included in the node and removed from its children, (2) if a variable can take multiple values that lead to the same recommendations, the largest set of such values can be grouped as < other >.

sections.heading: 1.3 Comparing the Decision Tree with Clinical Guidelines
sections.text: Finally, the decision tree is compared by experts with the CG. These experts should be medical experts who are briefly trained in the assessment method and reading the decision tree. Experts must verify that the treatments recommended by the tree are consistent with the CG, and review the CG to ensure that none of the recommendations contained in the CG are missing from the tree.

sections.heading: 2 Results
sections.text: The general method presented above was applied to the ASTI Criticism Module for Type 2 Diabetes.

sections.heading: 2.1 Generating Input Vectors
sections.text: The submissions of the critical ASTI module relate to (a) the clinical condition of the patient, (b) the treatment history of the patient, (c) the new treatment proposed by the physician, and (d) the efficiency and tolerability of the current treatment. Dosages have been taken into account, applying the following rule: If the proposed treatment is the same as the current treatment, the dose is understood to be modifiable: reduced if the problem identified is poorly tolerated, and increased if the problem identified is low in efficiency. In order to exclude unrealistic combinations, a few rules have been applied, e.g. if the current treatment is a diet, there can be no drug intolerance. sections.heading: 2.3 Comparing the Decision Tree with Clinical Guidelines
sections.text: We asked two doctors to compare the Decision Tree with the original CG. Experts found the Decision Tree easy to read, even though one of them was initially confused by the use of only two layers of treatment intent on the tree. Experts searched the tree for the therapeutic recommendations expressed in the CG and found that none of them was missing, and also made sure that the different branches of the tree led to the same recipe as the CG. Consequently, the experts considered the tree to be CG compliant.
